review.title: Harmony search to solve the container storage problem with different container types
review.abstract: This paper presents an adaptation of the harmony search algorithm to solve the storage allocation problem for inbound and outbound containers. This problem is studied considering multiple container type (regular, open side, open top, tank, empty and refrigerated) which lets the situation more complicated, as various storage constraints appeared. The objective is to find an optimal container arrangement which respects their departure dates, and minimize the re-handle operations of containers. The performance of the proposed approach is verified comparing to the results generated by genetic algorithm and LIFO algorithm.

metadata.title: Harmony search to solve the container storage problem with different container types

sections.text: Algorithm for solving the problem of warehouse allocation for incoming and outgoing containers. This problem is investigated taking into account several container types (regular, open, top, tank, empty and refrigerated), making the situation more complicated as various storage restrictions occurred. The aim is to find an optimal container arrangement that respects their departure dates and minimizes container handling operations. The performance of the proposed approach is checked against results generated by genetic algorithm and LIFO algorithm.General terms container storage problem, metaheuristics. Keywords harmony search, genetic algorithm, transport planning, metaheuristics, optimization, container storage

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: It is a complex process, as it is closely related to the routing of cranes and trucks. This paper focuses on the optimisation of the allocation of domestic and foreign containers. It falls into the category of persistent problems. It examines the extent to which these states are able to develop.

sections.heading: 3. PROBLEM FORMULATION
sections.text: In this section, we explain our evolutionary approach by presenting the applied mathematical formula based on the following assumptions:

sections.heading: 3.1 Assumptions
sections.text: In this thesis, we assume that: First, the containers are unloaded from the ship and transferred to the storage area, which awaits allocation to the permissible locations of the storage block. In order to unload a container, all the above-mentioned containers must be handled. Each container has a departure time. The initial condition of the storage blocks, available places, is known and must be taken into account in the loading planning. Containers are of different types (dry, open, open, tank, empty and refrigerated) Containers have the same sizeThe storage area in the port consists of several blocks which can be equipped with a power connection for storing refrigerated containers or regular blocks for the other container types. Figure 1 shows an example of a storage area.

sections.heading: 4. HARMONY SEARCH
sections.text: The harmony search algorithm is designed to mimic the behavior of the musician. HS is based on the analogy to the process of music improvisation in search of the best harmony. Harmony in music is analogous to the vector of the optimization solution, and the ideal harmony corresponds to the optimal solution. Musical harmony is improved after practicing based on the pitches played by each instrument. Also, the fitness function is improved by iteration, making derived information unnecessary. Figure 3 shows this analogy. HS does not require initial values for decision variables. In addition, it uses a stochastic random search based on harmony memory rate and pitch adjustment rate. Compared to previous meta-heuristic optimization algorithms, the HS algorithm imposes fewer mathematical requirements. Thus, it can easily be used for various types of technical optimization problems. [15] The harmony search algorithm successfully became the problem of storage drome15].

sections.heading: 4.1 Parameters initialization
sections.text: In this step the optimization problem is specified: Minimize (or maximize) f (x); xi Xi, i = 1,2,..., NWhere: f (x) is an objective function x is the solution vector consisting of decision variables xi Xi is the set of possible values for each decision variable Xi = {xi (1), xi (2),..., xi (K)} for discrete variables N is the number of decision variables K is the number of possible values for each discrete variable. The algorithm parameters are also specified during this step, e.g.: The size of the harmonic memory (HMS) is the number of solutions in memory The harmonic memory rate (HMCR); 0 ≤ HMCR ≤ 1; its typical values range from 0.7 to 0.99 The pitch fit rate (PAR): 0 ≤ PAR ≤ 1; its selected value ranges from 0.1 to 0.5 improvisation number.

sections.heading: 4.3 New harmony improvisation
sections.text: The harmonic memory is initially crammed; a new harmonic vector x '= (x' 1, x '2,.., x' N) is generated and compared with existing solutions. It is maintained if it is better than the worst harmony. x 'is improvised by using the following two rates: harmonic memory rate pitch fit rate. The value for each decision variable is randomly selected based on a harmonic memory rate (HMCR). The value of this is selected from the pitches previously stored in HM for this decision variable with a probability HMCR. While it is selected from the set of all possible values for the corresponding decision variable, with a probability (1 - HMCR). sections.heading: 4.4 Harmony memory update
sections.text: The new solution is stored in the harmony memory if it is better than the worst of the existing solutions, and it respects all problem limitations. Steps (4.3) and (4.4) are repeated, while the cancellation criterion (maximum number of improvisations) is not met.

sections.heading: 5. EVOLUTION PROCEDURE
sections.text: The decision variables Ci, t (x, y, z, b) represent the possible locations for the containers according to the allocated storage area. Ci, t (x, y, z, b) used a four-dimensional structure representation. These dimensions each indicate the container coordinates in the plan (X, Y, Z) and the number of the assigned block. Figure 4 shows an example of the solution representationThe initial harmony memory is generated randomly and each stored solution must respect all problem constraints (equations (3) to (8). Afterwards, a new solution is improvised based on the process outlined in Section 4.3. This step is repeated until the termination criterion is met.

sections.heading: 6. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
sections.text: This algorithm stops if the solution does not improve after niter iterations. It is assumed that: n1, n2 and n3 are defined by the user, the containers of type NT, the number of individual containers of type Nc (T) and the number of memory blocks (Nstock _ refrig, Nstock _ reg) are defined by the user. HMCR = 0.95 and PAR = 0.1. The departure date of the container is also specified by the user.

sections.heading: 6.1 The number of containers type influence
sections.text: In this part, the influence of the container type number has been investigated, as it is an important factor in this problem. The algorithm is executed for different values of NT and each time the best fitness values of the first (Fi) and last iterations (Ff) are given. Furthermore, the execution time (TExe) is given. Population size is set to 50, the stop criteria (niters) to 20, n1 = n2 = n3 = 3, Nstock _ reg = 4 and Nstock _ refrig = 4. The simulation results are shown in Table 1. Based on these results, it is clear that the number of container types is important, the execution time and worse is the fitness value. It is obvious, as the complexity of the problem is directly related to the container type number and its storage limitations.

sections.heading: 6.2 The harmony memory size influence
sections.text: To investigate the importance of the harmonic memory, we have defined the following parameters: Nc (T) = 5 (dry, empty, open top, tank, refrigerator) with Nc (1) = 20, Nc (2) = 20 Nc (3) = 15, Nc (5) = 10, Nc (6) = 20. Niter = 50 n1 = n2 = n3 = 3 Nstock _ reg = 3, Nstock _ refrig = 3The population size (HMS) is variable, its influence on the fitness value is shown in Table 2.The results indicate that the size of the harmonic memory is higher, the value of the fitness function is better.

sections.heading: 7. COMPARATIVE STUDY
sections.text: The LIFO algorithm consists of storing the last container placed in a stack for the first time, and this principle is applied in most port container terminals, where manual planning is carried out based on experience and rules for allocating each container to a particular storage block. Ayachi et al., [1] proposed the genetic algorithm to solve the same problem (SSAP for multiple container types), which can be described as follows: First, a first generation is randomly generated, followed by a two-point crossover operator with two parents selected using the roulette wheel method, and the mutation operator consists of the permutation of two randomly selected container types of the same type. Five cases studied are defined by varying the container numbers and types to verify the performance of the three approaches.

sections.heading: 8. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In the real case, there are different types of containers such as refrigerated containers, open side, empty, dry, open top, tank... Each type of container has limitations on the allocation of storage space, which complicates the problem, i.e., refrigerated containers must be assigned to blocks equipped with the power supply, tank containers must be placed on top of each other, etc. Despite this difficulty, the proposed approach led to good results in a reasonable execution time. Experimental studies confirm this and show the effectiveness of applying the search for harmony in solving this problem. An important extension of this research would be to formulate the problem as dynamic storage space allocation in order to solve it and decide in real time.

[4] Chen, P., Fu, Z., Lim, A., Rodrigues, B., 2004, Port yard storage optimization.

Kim [12] presented a technique to estimate the rehandlings number for the next pick-up and the total number of rehandles to pick up all inbound containers in a bay.

Kim and Kim [13] proposed a cost model to estimate various cost components related to the import container handling and to determine subsequently the storage space and the number of transfer cranes required.
Also, in [14], a prediction model of unloading containers times and equipment utilization is presented.

[16] developed a heuristic algorithm to solve the yard truck scheduling and the storage allocation problems.

The Harmony search algorithm has been successfully applied to vehicle routing problem [6], hydrologic parameter calibration [15] and to the Storage space allocation problem [2] The HS algorithm includes five steps: parameters initialization, the harmony memory (HM) initialization, the new harmony improvisation, the harmony memory update and the check of termination criterion.

This problem is studied considering multiple container type (regular, open side, open top, tank, empty and refrigerated) which lets the situation more complicated, as various storage constraints appeared. The objective is to find an optimal container arrangement which respects their departure dates, and minimize the re-handle operations of containers. The performance of the proposed approach is verified comparing to the results generated by genetic algorithm and LIFO algorithm. General Terms Container storage problem, metaheuristics.
